data.title: We should only convert settings into the workspace settings section if certain preconditions are meet.
TypeScript must flag resource settings as resource settings otherwise they are treated as window settings
data.body: IMO all typescript settings which are currently not marked as window settings must be marked as resource settings. Window is the default and now for example all formatter settings are window settings which IMO doesn't make much sense. We should prefer resource of window if possible.

data.title: File marked as changed but there is no diff
data.body:
**Environment:**
- VSCode Version:  1.15.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open a file
2. Remove any character and type it again
3. Tab will indicate that file is changed
4. Use undo to make tab indicate, that file was not changed

Looks like VSCode checks operations history instead of real diff

**Reproduces without extensions:** Yes

data.title: Total breakdown of syntax highlighting with ES6 factory functions
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Fedora 26

Steps to Reproduce:

1. copy the code pasted below into vscode with Javascript as the language
2. observe the syntax highlighting fail

Please see the attached screen dump
![broken](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12832280/29964659-b1160702-8f02-11e7-939b-a5fb0de86590.png)


Reproduces without extensions: Yes

```js
    // Factory functions

    const createZombie = ({
        status = 1,
        width = 10,
        height = 10,
        xPosition,
        yPosition,
        color = "green"
    }) => ({
        status,
        width,
        height,
        xPosition,
        yPosition,
        color
    });

    const createHero = ({
        status = 1,
        width = 25,
        height = 50,
        xPosition,
        yPosition,
        color = "red"
    }) => ({
        status,
        width,
        height,
        xPosition,
        yPosition,
        color
    });
```

data.title: Check for provideDebugConfigurations not the provider
data.body:
I've verified that a debug type is shown in the environment menu, if there is a registered DebugConfigurationProvider. However, this DebugConfigurationProvider does not need to implement the provideDebugConfigurations.

This information is actually passed from the extension to VS Code: the IDebugConfigurationProvider has only a provideDebugConfigurations method if there is one in the extension.

Please fix this in September.

data.title: Assignment bot should ignore extensions table
IntelliSense for 'http' Node.js module does not work on macOS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Terminal
2. mkdir intellisense-demo
3. cd intellisense-demo
4. code .
5. Create a new index.js file with the following content
**// index.js
var http = require('http');
http.c**
6. launch suggestions ctrl+space

=> No suggestions

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

However, IntelliSense works for client-side javascript like "console.log" or "document.getElementById" and the likes...

2. `vscode-insiders .` in some folder
3. Notice that the unititle workspace also gets opened, which is fine however we should focus the window which the user explicitly opened

data.title: Search: ignore root folder that does not exist
data.body:
Related to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29738, once you have any root folder that does not exist, you can no longer do a search at all. I think we should fail more gracefully and still run the search for the other folders:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/29963844-83b5972c-8f08-11e7-865a-92af0ecb647c.png)

data.title: Diff editor no longer reveals change when file is open in an normal editor
data.body:
It reveals the editor's cursor position.

The scm resource command needs to be decoupled with the editor title's one.

data.title: Opening an old .code-workspace file provides no help to the user
data.body:
1. I am a user who used vscode insiders for MR workspace as soon as it came out, so I got the .code-workspace file in the old format
2. After a month I am coming back to VSCode -> I use the "open workspace" action to load my workspace from 1.
3. The file is outputed as simple text and no help is shown

At the very least we could detect if a user just opened a .code-workspace file and if we can not parse it we could provide a nice info message so the user is not puzzled as to why his old .code-workspace is not working any more

data.title: Prompt user whether he wants to close window
data.body:
Feature request.
I usually start my dev server via embedded terminal. In case of two screens i often missclick to the "close window" button. Is it possible to prompt me whether i want to close window if there is an working process in embedded terminal?

data.title: Feature Request: Cursor should automatically jump to next line when "Comment line" shortcut key is held
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

This is a Feature Request.

Currently, Holding the shortcut key to "Comment Line" does nothing. So, If I want to comment multiple consecutive lines, I have to first select all those lines/add cursors and then comment them. This behaviour is different than most IDEs and text editors and a teensy bit annoying. 

As holding down "Comment Line" shortcut(Ctrl + "/")  currently does nothing. My suggestion is to add a system so if the shortcut is held for more than 2-3 seconds(Configurable) the cursor will jump to next line and comment it and keep doing that until you've released the shortcut keys. 

This behaviour is similar to other IDEs and editors making it easier for people coming from other IDEs/editors to adapt vscode and also makes better use of shortcut. 

If this sounds like a reasonable request, I would absolutely love to work on it.

data.title: Typescript use of React SFC (stateless functional component) usage generates spurious error highlighting
Feature request: tag scrolling

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 8

I don't find minimap much useful when I need to scroll up and down in my file. Unless there is a large block of switch or comments, I cannot make out where to jump unless I'm aware of the position of the code I'm searching.

Here's feature request for alternative way for fast scrolling.
- By default, auto-tag all method/functions and classes in a file.
- In place of minimap, show all the tags. Except for a large file, ensure the tag list fits in one screen. Scrolling for tag list would likely defeat the purpose. Those who are disciplined enough will keep the file short enough.
- As an enhancement, allow  custom tags.
- Allow hotkeys/quick access buttons for toggle jump between last two locations.

Thanks,
-Shailesh

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No
